pullRequest.title: Feature enhancement to Surface Placement
pullRequest.bodyText:
Added in the relative to scene surface placement enhancement in the Surface Placement sample. Requirements also included adding a scene to the existing sample, adding a slider for the z-value and updating the readme.
Couple of points:


I update the z-value in the slider implementation and implemented it consistently with the layout of creating the initial graphics rather than using a loop, be interested to know if that was a reasonable decision in terms of ease of understanding what's going on.


I made the label text colour blue as per the design, there was some discussion about different colours but I think it's overall readable in the blue. I increased the font and symbol size a bit which helped.


Line 182 - Wasn't sure if the word 'controls' is standard in the naming of JavaFX boxes or if it had just been used previously. Could rename the radio button box to actually mention it since there's now 2 bits of functionality.


Thanks!

nodes.bodyText:
We generally want to have the imports in a specific order, with the Runtime imports coming last.
Luckily we can set up the IDE to take care of that for us!
Theres some details in Simone's recent PR showing how to set it up:
#528 (comment)
Good catch on this - the sample was previously called elevation mode in Java, but it was renamed surface placement to be consistent with the other sdks!
Since this is getting to be quite a lot of UI setup, you would want to make this sample into an FXML one, and define this slider (as well as the toggle buttons) in the main.fxml file.
I think a loop would be fine here, since it's quite clear that we're updating all the graphics in all the graphics overlays with one specific Point

Thinking from a performance point of view (which might not entirely be in the spirit of samples):
Every time one of these slider event fires, these two lines are repeating the .getX(), .getY() and .getSpatialReference() calls. We know these aren't likely to change. The only thing we really change is the Z-value. So to save ourselves doing that, we could just save these values into variables outside of this event listener, and refer to them.
What you definitely can do is save the spatial reference as a varialbe outside of this lambda, and re-use it, since it'll be the same for both points
I'll leave it again to @Rachael-E to decide whether this should be updated, or left as is for user clarity. Either way, might be a helpful observation regarding not repeating method calls?
There's generally no need to 'chop' the method chaining if the line doesn't get too long 😄

You can define a lot of this stuff in the CSS file itself, so that it's easier for the users to focus just on the control elements.
Once you do sliderVBox.getStyleClass().add("panel-region");, all the CSS rules targeting this class would apply, and then you could just apply the style class to both the slider and the radio-button vboxes.
Check out these files from animate images with image overlay for some inspiration:
https://github.com/Esri/arcgis-runtime-samples-java/blob/master/scene/animate-images-with-image-overlay/src/main/resources/animate_images_with_image_overlay/style.css
https://github.com/Esri/arcgis-runtime-samples-java/blob/master/scene/animate-images-with-image-overlay/src/main/resources/animate_images_with_image_overlay/main.fxml
You could also extract the styling from the VBoxes, Slider, and future RadioButtons.

While we have this sample open, let's update the JavaFX version to 11.0.2.
You'll also need to include the module 'javafx.fxml' when you make this into an fxml sample.
Lastly, on line 77, lets update:
gradleVersion = '6.5.1'
You'll also have to change this version number in a line inside \gradle\wrapper\gradle-wrapper.properties

You can get away with using double, the primitive type here:

  
    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                    Double zValueFromSlider = zValueSlider.getValue();
          
          
            
                    double zValueFromSlider = zValueSlider.getValue();
          
      
    
    
  

The IDE does a better job at explaining why than I would ever do:

The Double class wraps a value of the primitive type double in an object. An object of type Double contains a single field whose type is double.
In addition, this class provides several methods for converting a double to a String and a String to a double, as well as other constants and methods useful when dealing with a double.
